page.title: 19CHANGES:LEASINGHAM (PART2)
page.content: To the south of the village was a land army canteen.Where the village hall now stands was a wooden 'Boy's Club'and on Chapel Lane there was a water tower.There was{only one shop and the Duke of Wellington public house.A{rail -way line,}which carried one goods train daily, ran across Hall Farm north -west through the village. Between 1961 and 1971,estates of bungalows and detached houses were built and the{population rose by 103% to 1110.The 1981 census showed 525 households in the village with 1517 people. In 1981,27% of Leasingham's working population was employed by the{Armed {Forces-}principally at{R.A.F.Cranwell 5 miles away.Another 5% were employed as civilians.Without the jobs at R.A.F Cranwell the village would probably have died in the 1950's and 1960's.'
